Yes, this is what I was trying to get at. 

Think of it as allowing another=
 runtime view onto your
test cases. The test runner provides one, fairly te=
rse, view:
this test passed, or it failed on this assertion. This is
by far=
 the most useful view. 

The assertion
log provides a deeper view into the =
test run, by leveraging
information about the test run that you've already =
built into
your test cases. If you don't find that view useful, then
you wo=
n't use it and no worries. There are many views in 
Eclipse that I do not f=
ind useful, but there may come a day
when I will.

> > I'd like to make a case for adding logging of assertions=

> > I've been using junit for many years, and something that I=

ces is
> > that it is often helpful to get warm fuzzy feedback that your te=
sts
> > are running and asserting what you think they are asserting.
> >
> =
> I notice that I'm not alone in this; I see there are several threads
> > =
where people were looking for this feature
> > (http://tech.groups.yahoo.co=
m/group/junit/message/17845 "how to log
> > junit tests", http://tech.group=
s.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/18762
> > "junit 4 & logging",

ech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/12000 "Log4J Logging
> > in JUnit"=
)
> >
> I am just going to be frank here. Yes, many people have said they w=
ant
> to log assertions in tests because they want the warm fuzzy feedback
=
> that their tests are running and assertion what they think they are
> ass=
erting. Logging is just one, and in my opinion a bad, way to do
> this. I b=
elieve it is much better to write simpler tests.
> > 1) eliminating redunda=
nt logging statements - Many logging statements
> > in a JUnit test case si=
mply output information that you've already
> > told JUnit about in your as=
sertions. Developers often put these in as
> > a 'sanity check' to verify t=
hat the test is doing what they expected.
> >
> If your tests need such a s=
anity check, then I believe they should be
> simpler.
> > 2) improving asse=
rtion messages - it's often the case that the
> >
> > first time you see th=
e message for an assertion will be when the
> > assertion fails, which may =
not happen until you run a regression test
> > many moons after you coded t=
he test. Unless you see the message
> > displayed when you are developing t=
he test, you won't realize that the
> > message - if you provided one - is =
not be very helpful. Better
> > assertion messages also help to communicate=
 to a developer what the
> > point of the assertion is both when it fails a=
nd when reading the
> > test.
> >
> If you aren't going to think about the =
failure message when you write
> it, then don't write one.
> > 3) see finer=
-grain test results. Every assertion is a mini-test on its
> > own, but JUn=
it these mini-tests are invisible until they fail.
> >
> Absolutely not. As=
sertions are not mini-tests. A test is a test. If
> you have multiple unrel=
ated assertions in a test, then move them into
> their own tests. This lead=
s to a number of benefits (more accurate
> test count metrics, more informa=
tion when a test fails, easier to
> isolate the cause of a failure).
> > 4)=
 by making logging easy, it can help to avoid the
> > using-system-outs-ins=
tead-of-asserts syndrome, where new junit test
> > writers will write "test=
 cases" that actually just write a bunch of
> > stuff to the console that t=
he test writer then eyeballs for expected
> > results
> >
> Why would anyon=
e use JUnit to spit things out to the console? If they
> want output on the=
 console, and they're not just using that as a way
> to learn to use JUnit,=
 then they shouldn't use JUnit.
> > There are some problems with logging as=
sertions that I have
> > encountered:
> >
> > 1) if iterating over a collec=
tion and asserting each element, your log
> > can be overwhelmed. Maybe it =
would be useful to have some way of
> > hinting that a particular assertion=
 should not create notifications;
> > maybe not.
> >
> I don't even want to=
 think about how slowly tests will run, and how
> much time I would waste d=
eciding which tests should log what and when.
> It's much easier just to ad=
d logging where I want it.
> > Is there any appetite out there for adding a=
ssertion logging (or
> > assertion notification) into the junit 4 framework=
? I would be
> > happy to do the work if I thought it would be accepted int=
o the
> > main junit distribution. Or maybe this capability already exists
=
> > in some way in junit 4 that I am not aware of?
> >
> Yes, there is such=
 an appetite, but I hope there is a bigger appetite
> not to include it.
